name: Rachel Perkins
description: The moving image has helped tell First Peoples stories through documentary, films and TV shows, with acclaimed director, producer and screenwriter Rachel Perkins contributing significantly to these stories.

key_work.title: Spotlights: Rachel Perkins
key_work.brief_description: An Australian film and television director, producer, and screenwriter. She is known for her films Radiance (1998), One Night the Moon (2001), Bran Nue Dae (2009) and Jasper Jones (2017). Rachel discusses the merits of film and television from an Indigenous perspective, particularly in relation to audience.

start.title: Cleverman
start.creator_credit: Ryan Griffen, Damir Peranovic, ABC-TV (Australia), Goalpost Pictures, Pukeko Pictures, Jacob Nash and Jane Allen
start.brief_description: Cleverman stormed onto ABC TV in 2016 as a dystopian sci-fi with a difference. With predominantly Indigenous cast and senior crew, the series explores a series of Aboriginal origin stories in a contemporary context, with political nuance touching on themes of class, racism and power.

constellations_other.description: Jedda was the first fully funded Australian feature to be shot on colour film. It was also the first Australian film with Aboriginal actors in lead roles, however, it reflects a deeply problematic time in Australian history.

start.title: Bran Nue Dae
start.creator_credit: Rachel Perkins, MIFF Premiere Fund, Jimmy Chi and Reg Cribb
start.brief_description: In the Summer of 1965 a young man is filled with the life of the idyllic old pearling port Broome - fishing, hanging out with his mates and his girl. However his mother returns him to the religious mission for further schooling. After being punished for an act of youthful rebellion, he runs away from the mission on a journey that ultimately leads him back home.

constellations_other.description: Yanmeeyarr, meaning ‘flickering in firelight’, shares how light and shadow are at the core of the moving image.
